The International Paper - Natchez Mill is committed to operating in a manner that is safe for the Natchez Mill employees, the public and the environment.  As part of this committment, the Natchez Mill has established a system to help ensure safe operation of the processes at the facility.  One component of this system is a risk management program (RMP) that helps manage the risks at the Natchez Mill and that complies with the requirements of the Environmental Protection Ageny's (EPA's) regulation 40 CFR part 68, Accidental Release Prevention Requirements: Risk Management Programs (the RMP rule).  One of the requirements of the RMP rule is to submit a risk management plan (RMPlan) describing the risk management program at the Natchez Mill.  This document is intended to satisfy the RMPlan requirement of the RMP rule (CFR 68 150 through 185) and to provide the public with a description of the risk management program at the Natchez MIll.

Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

The Natchez Mill is committed to the safety of its workers and the public, and to the preservation of the environment, through the prevention of accidental releases of hazardous substances. The Natchez Mill implements reasonable controls to prevent foreseeable releases of hazardous substances.  In the event of an accidental release, the Natchez Mill controls, contains, cleans up the release in a manner that will be safe for workers and will help prevent injury to the public or the environment.

The Natchez Mill and Regulated Substances

The Natchez Mill is a dissolving pulp mill with 100% chlorine dioxide bleaching operations.  The facility handles three substances regulated by the RMP rule in sufficient quantities to be covered by the RMP rule.  They are all a part of the dissolving pulp process and are covered under program level 3.

     *  sulfur dioxide used for pH control in the bleach plant and machine room (313,000 pounds maximum)
     *  chlorine used to prepare so

dium hypochlorite for use in the bleach plant (360,000 pounds maximum)
     *  chlorine dioxide used to bleach the dissolving pulp (22,000 pounds maximum)

Offsite Consequence Analysis

The RMP rule requires the Natchez Mill to perform an offsite consequence analysis for the following scenarios:

     *  one worst-case scenario for sulfur dioxide
     *  one alternate release scenario for each of sulfur dioxide, chlorine and chlorine dioxide

The following information summarizes this offsite consequence analysis performed by Trinity Consultants, of Dallas, TX.

Sulfur Dioxide

The worst-case scenario for sulfur dioxide is failure of the largest storage tank (313,336 pounds).  This potential release scenario could possibly impact public receptors such as schools, residences, hospitals, correctional facilities, recreational and industrial facilities.  There are also potential environmental receptors of national and state parks and forests, and officially designated wildlife santuaries, preserves or refuges. 

The alternate release scenario for sulfur dioxide is a tank overfill and a release of 50 gallons (568 pounds) detected and stopped within 10 minutes.  Public receptors possibly impacted are residences, recreation and industrial areas.  There are no environmental receptors impacted. 
 
Chlorine

The alternate release scenario for chlorine is a gasket leak of 10 gallons/minute (3675 pounds total), detected and stopped within 30 minutes.  Public receptors possibly impacted are residences, recreation and industrial areas.  There are no environmental receptors impacted.  

Chlorine Dioxide

The alternate release scenario for chlorine dioxide is a liquid solution leak into the diked containment area around the largest of the two onsite storage tanks to 80% of the dike height (506 pounds) that evaporates over one hours time.  Public receptors possibly impacted are residences, recreation and industrial areas.  There are no environmental receptors impacted.  

Accidental

Release Prevention Program and Chemical Specific Prevention Steps

The RMP rule requires a Program 3 prevention program for the dissolving pulp process.  The following paragraphs describe the prevention program elements at the Natchez Mill that apply to these units.

PROCESS SAFETY INFORMATION.  The Natchez Mill maintains a variety of technical documents that are used to help ensure safe operation of the dissolving pulp process.  Material safety data sheets (MSDSs) document the physical properties of hazardous substances handled at the mill, including the RMP regulated substances in the covered process.  There are engineering design documents that show proper operating parameters, design basis and the process overview.  There are also references to applicable codes and standards.

PROCESS HAZARD ANALYSIS.  The Natchez Mill has performed all inital PHAs and is in the process of revalidating all PHAs.  The PHAs help identify and control process hazards.  HAZOP and checklists were used extensively in the initial PHAs and in the revalidation process being used to update the PHAs.  This is a technique to verify the accuracy of original PHAs, ensure corrective actions were completed, studies Management of Change documentation and conducts a facility siting and human factors study.  The reviews include items that help ensure that the Natchez Mill operates and maintains the equipment in a manner consistent with the applicable design specifications, codes, standards and regulations.

OPERATING PROCEDURES.  The Natchez Mill has developed and maintains operating procedures to define how tasks related to process operations should be performed.  The operating procedures are used to (1) train employees and contractors and (2) serve as reference guides for appropriate actions to be taken during both normal operations and process upsets.  They are reviewed annually.

TRAINING.  The Natchez Mill trains personnel in the operating procedures to help ensure safe and effective performan

ce of their assigned tasks.  Refresher training is provided annually.

MAINTENANCE.  The Natchez Mill properly maintains the process equipment.  The Natchez Mill maintenance program includes (1) procedures to safely guide workers in their maintenance tasks, (2) worker training in the maintenance department procedures, and (3) an inspection and testing program to help identify equipment deterioration and damage before the equipment fails.  Procedures are reviewed annually for accuracy.  Refresher training is given to appropriate employees.  Preventive maintenance routes are performed on a regular basis (daily, weekly, monthly, annually as necessary).  Maintenance personnel are specialty task trained (STT) to where only those workers receiving the STT training can perform work on the covered systems.

COMPLIANCE AUDITS.  The Natchez Mill has compliance audits performed every three years of covered processes to verify that the processes are operating in compliance with the requirements of Process Safety Management and the RMP rule.  The audits are conducted by trained corporate personnel.  A compliance audit report is prepared after each audit and any deficiencies noted by the audit team are corrected in a timely manner.  Our last audit was in May, 1998.

INCIDENT INVESTIGATION.  The Natchez Mill investigates all incidents that could reasonably have resulted in a serious injury to personnel, the public or the environment.  The Natchez Mill encourages all employees to identify and report any incident requiring investigation to the regulatory compliance technician, EHS cooridanator, area management personnel, etc.  Also, there is a near miss hotline where incidents can be reported anonymously.  The results of the investigation are documented, recommendations are resolved and appropriate process enhancements are implemented.

CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS - SULFUR DIOXIDE.  Industry standards are followed at the Natchez Mill to help ensure safe handling of sulfur dio

xide.  The sulfur dioxide vendor supplies liquid sulfur dioxide via a Department of Transportation (DOT)-approved tank truck and follows DOT standards when unloading into the storage tank.  There are two storage tanks available and it is standard practice to use only one at a time.  The tank being used is only filled up to 3/4 full.  There are area SO2 detectors and alarms to indicate a release.  Level indicators on the tanks are checked by operating personnel once every 8 hours.  Operating and maintenance personnel are refresher trained annually on the system and proper procedures.

CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS - CHLORINE.  Industry standards are followed at the Natchez Mill to help ensure safe handling of chlorine.  The chlorine vendor supplies liquid chlorine via a DOT-approved rail car.  There are at most two rail cars on site at any one time and it is standard practice to only use from one at a time.  There are Cl2 monitors and alarms to indicate releases.  There are cameras for control room personnel to monitor the rail cars.  The system is piped to scrubbers to treat any released chlorine.  Operating and maintenance personnel are refresher trained annually on the system and proper procedures.

CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS - CHLORINE DIOXIDE.  Industry standards are followed at the Natchez Mill to help ensure safe generation and handling of chlorine dioxide.  It is generated on site in an SVP Lite R8 generator.  There are two storage tanks with diked containment areas around each.  Releases into the dikes will go into the mill process sewer to be diluted with bleach plant effluents.  There are ClO2 monitors and alarms to detect releases and system vents are piped to the ClO2 scrubbers (6 total).  Operating and maintenance personnel are refresher trained annually on the system and proper procedures.

Five-Year Accident History

There have been no releases of regulated substances at the Natchez Mill in the last 5 years that have resulted in consequen

ces of interest (i.e., deaths, injuries, or significant property damage on site; or known deaths, injuries, evaculations, sheltering-in-place, property damage, or environmental damage off site).  

Emergency Response Programs

The Natchez Mill has an excellent emergency response team on site, with 24 hour medical personnel on site also.  Personnel receive training approximately monthly and members are specialty trained (ERT, EMT, HAZMAT).  The Natchez Mill has established a written emergency response plan that complies with the RMP rule and with other federal contingency plan regulations.  This plan has been communicated to local emergency response officials through the civil defense office and the fire department.  Regular dialogue is maintained between the Natchez Mill and the local emergency planning committee (LEPC).  The Natchez Mill conducts periodic drills and participates in the annual LEPC community drill.

Planned Changes to Improve Safety

The Natchez Mill strives to improve the safety of the processes.  Improvement items come from annual review of procedures, the management of change program, PHA ravalidations.  A recently completed item was to re-route the SO2 pulldown system to the Flakt scrubber in the power house and away from the bleach plant.
